content.text: State the two conditions necessary for the helicopter to remain in equilibrium
condition 1
condition 2
The mass of the helicopter is \(3200\mathrm{kg}\)
Calculate the change in the gravitational potential energy of the helicopter as it rises from the ground to \(1500 \text{m}\)
change in gravitational potential energy =
Fig. 1.1 shows a helicopter which is stationary at a height of \(1500 \text{m}\) above the ground
On Fig. 1.2, label a point on the graph where the acceleration is:
• zero with ‘1’
• negative with ‘2’
• decreasing with ‘3’
Explain, in terms of forces, the changes in motion which occur from when the parachutist leaves the hot-air balloon until point A
Fig. 1.2 shows a vertical speed–time graph for a parachutist who jumps from a stationary hot-air balloon
The parachutist jumps from the balloon at time \(=\) 0 and reaches the ground at B. The point A indicates when the parachute opens
Calculate the kinetic energy stored in the cricket ball immediately before it is caught
kinetic energy = .........
It takes 0.12 s to catch the ball and bring it to rest
Calculate the average force exerted on the ball
average force = .........
As the student catches the ball, she moves her hands backwards
Explain the effect of this action on the student's hands
A student catches a cricket ball. The speed of the ball immediately before it is caught is \(18 \text{m / s}\). The mass of the cricket ball is \(160 \text{g}\)
Fig. 3.1 shows a person moving across an ice-covered pond to reach a ball on the ice
Explain why this way of moving across the ice is safer than walking. Use your understanding of pressure in your answer
Fig. 3.2 shows a side view of the pond with a layer of ice floating freely on the water
The surface area of the pond is \(5.0 \text{m}^2\)
The mass of the ice is \(690 \text{kg}\)
The density of water is \(1000 \text{kg} / \text{m}^3\)
Point X is \(0.45 \text{m}\) below the ice
Calculate the pressure at point X due to the ice and the water
The temperature of a fixed mass of gas at constant volume is decreased
State and explain, in terms of particles, how the pressure of the gas changes
State the value of absolute zero in \(^\circ \mathrm{C}\)
value of absolute zero = .........\(^\circ \mathrm{C}\)
Explain what is meant by the term absolute zero. Refer to particles in your answer

Cylinder 1 contains \(350 \text{cm}^3\) of gas at a pressure of \(9.0 \times 10^4 \text{Pa}\). The gas is transferred to cylinder 2 and the pressure increases to \(1.6 \times 10^5 \text{Pa}\). The temperature remains constant
Calculate the volume of cylinder 2
Show that the mass of air in the room is \(79\mathrm{kg}\)
The power of the heater is 1100W. The specific heat capacity of air is \(1000 \text{J} / (\text{kg} \degree \text{C})\)
Calculate the time taken to increase the temperature of the air in the room from \(16.0^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\) to \(20.0^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\)
Suggest one reason why the time calculated in (a)(ii) is the minimum time needed to increase the temperature of the air in the room from \(16.0^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\) to \(20.0^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\)
Fig. 5.1 shows an electric heater used to heat a room
The dimensions of the room are \(4.5 \text{m} \times 6.1 \text{m} \times 2.4 \text{m}\)
The density of air is \(1.2 \text{kg} /\text{m}^3\)
Fig. 5.2 shows a cross-section of a double-glazed window in the room
State the main methods of thermal energy transfer from the room to outside which are reduced by this type of window
State the types of wave that P-waves and S-waves can be modelled as
P-waves
S-waves
The velocity of a P-wave in the Earth's solid crust is \(7.2 \text{km / s}\) and its frequency is \(4.5 \text{Hz}\)
Calculate the wavelength of this P-wave
wavelength = .........
Two types of seismic waves are P-waves and S-waves

The angle \(x\) is \(56^{\circ}\)

angle of refraction = .........

All the cells are reversed

The three cells are identical and have zero resistance
The resistors \(\mathsf{R}_1\) , \(\mathsf{R}_2\) and \(\mathsf{R}_3\) are identical

content.text: State how \(\beta \)-decay changes the nucleus of an atom

A radiation detector used in a laboratory detects a background count rate of 30 counts/ min. A radioactive source is placed in front of the radiation detector. The initial reading on the detector is 550 counts/ min. The half-life of the source is 25 minutes
Calculate the expected reading on the detector after 75 minutes
reading = .........counts/min
State **two** safety precautions taken when moving, using or storing radioactive sources in a laboratory

Suggest why countries that are a significant distance from the Equator experience significant temperature variation throughout the year
Fill in the gaps in the paragraph about a star much more massive than the Sun
The stage that follows the stable state in the life cycle of the star is the
stage
It then explodes as a supernova to form a .................................. , this leaves behind a
or a
A galaxy is moving away from the Earth with a speed of \(33 000 \text{km / s}\)
The value of the Hubble constant is \(2.2 \times 10^{- 18}\) per second
Calculate the distance from the galaxy to the Earth. Give your answer in light-years
distance = .........light-years
